abstracts.cdata!:
Project outcome is satisfactory, and
            project sustainability is regards as likely. The overall
            performances of both the World Bank and the Borrower are
            regarded as satisfactory. General lessons highlighted from
            this project include these: 1) Some Bank rules prevent
            public institutions from participating in bidding, thus
            limiting the pool of qualified organizations which could
            contribute to the realization of projects. 2) The Bank
            should avoid granting short closing date extensions, as this
            approach is counterproductive for project operations.
            Project-specific lessons noted were these: 1) An effective
            outreach program is key to reaching potential beneficiaries
            in the informal sector. 2) Special attention should be given
            to the choice of training sponsors. To that end,
            institutional sponsors and enterprises should be given
            priority. 3) The project demonstrated that craftsmen did not
            respond very well to demands for training. It is, thus,
            necessary to work with their associations to sensitize
            craftsmen on the role they can play as trainers for the
            less-skilled labor force and to provide additional
            incentives. 4) Allocation of public funds on a competitive
            basis (i.e., with public vocational training institutes
            competing with private institutions) can reduce costs and
            increase responsiveness of public spending on skills
            development. 5) Lack of complementary inputs (water, credit,
            equipment, markets) tend to limit the impact on
            beneficiaries. This suggests the needs to link subprojects
            better with other projects and interventions." 6)
            Existence of accountability mechanisms for a Fund would
            enhance its efficiency. Lessons pertaining to the research
            agency for employment promotion (AGEPE) included: 1)
            Organizations like the Observatory must have enough autonomy
            to avoid the sclerosis of the bureaucracy and enough
            influence to get information it requires from others. 2)
            Successfully building organizational capacity requires a
            careful analysis of incentives, such as financial incentives
            for competent staff to join, stay and be productive in the
            organization. It should also examine incentives to establish
            networks and linkages across organizational borders".
            3) One major weakness that impeded the performance of the
            Observatory was the limited human capacity available for
            labor market analysis. A lesson to be learned is that
            building an institution like the Observatory requires a long
            commitment of time and effort. 4) Although Observatories
            seem to have failed in may African countries, these
            organizations are still relevant, especially as there are no
            think tanks in those countries. Their success will depend on
            a careful design as advised above and on the dissemination
            strategy put in place.
